messageBody:
I usually use something like:

// caveat: not real code...
void testInvalidDBConnection() {
Connection conn = null;
try {
String ignored = myTestClassInstance.getImportantValue(conn);
fail("Should have thrown exception in last call...");
}
catch(DBUnavailableException expected) {
assertTrue(true);
}
catch(Exception anyOther) {
// this catch may not be necessary...
fail("Unexpeceted exception thrown: " + anyOther);
}
}


As J. B. Rainsberger points out, JUnit will automatically catch
exceptions thrown, which is why the second catch probably isn't needed.
You may want to add it if the method "getImportantValue()" throws other
exceptions of interest...


HTH,
Jim Cheesman
